column3: Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/p4762_4bb61b45359b98632c64fca2f3640d276ab75244/ for binaries and test log.\nThis test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-te
Why keep chunks by date instead of by total size (as bitcoind does anyway)?\n

Date is more human-centric and useful to some queries.  "ls -l" will therefore produce useful, date-based information.  "ls -l" tells you which files contain data from >= 2014, etc.  No need to scan the files to determine that.\n
TheBlueMatt: also it makes it more straightforward to extend the range; just add a file per month, the other files will stay the same\n
Well, the reason for choosing size as split criterion is because of pruning: you prune entire files, so ideally they are approximately equal in size.\n

Let me slay this shed painting, of which I am also guilty, by noting that the script fully supports split-by-file-size as a criterion, via configuration file setting.

The default is split-by-size.  Default of "max_out_sz" is 1000L \* 1000 \* 1000 bytes.

This commit adds a non-default split-by-date, enabled via config file.

It is my fault for not being more explicit about the capabilities

@jgarzik thanks for clearing that up!

It is my fault for not actually ever having read the code...
Let's get that last comment fixed and merge this\n
Merged via d800dcc, replacing the "year" with "month" in README.md\n
I think you meant month here (and maybe not _timestamp, but _month?)\n
The config file variable name is correct, but the English description is not.  Will fix.\n
